items.title: US demands EU reverse new climate rules to allow surge in gas imports
bullets: • US and Qatar, two of the three largest LNG exporters in the world, sent a letter to the European Union
• The EU should either completely repeal or substantially cut back the new rules, according to the letter
• The directive requires gas exporters to the 27-country bloc to show they protect human rights and are cutting their planet-heating emissions

• Zhang escaped from house arrest in Mexico in July while awaiting extradition to the US, where a warrant has been issued for his arrest on money laundering charges

items.title: How two Texas redistricting cases, 37 years apart, set the stage for the latest congressional redraw
bullets: • In 1987, Tony Campos sued the city of Baytown in a landmark case that opened the door for Black and Hispanic voters to join together to bring voting rights challenges across the country

• Marc Campos' father died in 2023, the year before his case was overturned and two years before the Texas Legislature cited that new court precedent as Republicans positioned themselves to grab five new seats

• What connects you to the land you live in and your fellow citizens? We'll read every response and share a selection of them in a forthcoming editorial
• Too often, patriotism has been used as a tool of division rather than unity - defined from podium rather than people

items.title: Mental exercise can reverse a brain change linked to aging, study finds
bullets: • A Montreal neurologist says cognitive training can boost levels of a brain chemical that typically declines with age
• The increase "is not huge," says Étienne de Villers-Sidani, a neurologist at McGill University in Montreal
• It's significant, considering that you get a 2.5% decrease per decade normally just with aging, he says

items.title: How algae learned to harness the Sun without getting burned
bullets: • A pigment known as siphonein helps marine green algae continue photosynthesizing efficiently, even under intense light
• The discovery could inspire new solar technologies that mimic nature’s built-in protection systems
• A day of strong sunlight can spoil the process of photosynthesis, the way plants and other organisms convert sunlight into energy

items.title: They were drilling off Oregon. What they found could shake all of California
bullets: • Scientists have uncovered evidence that megaquakes in the Pacific Northwest might trigger California’s San Andreas Fault
• This finding hints that the next ‘Big One’ could set off a devastating one-two seismic punch along the coast
• A magnitude 9 or higher earthquake in this region would unleash catastrophic shaking, followed by tsunamis and landslides

items.title: Atlantic dolphins are dying much younger. Scientists sound the alarm
bullets: • Common dolphins in the North Atlantic are living significantly shorter lives, with female longevity dropping seven years since the 1990s
• Researchers found this decline by analyzing stranded dolphins, revealing a 2.4% drop in population growth linked to bycatch deaths and environmental pressures
• The findings expose flaws in traditional counting methods and call for adaptive conservation measures

items.title: Scientists stumble on a hidden quantum trick in 2D materials
bullets: • Researchers have found that 2D materials can self-form microscopic cavities that trap light and electrons, altering their quantum behavior
• With a miniaturized terahertz spectroscope, the team observed standing light-matter waves without needing mirrors
• The discovery offers a new method to manipulate exotic quantum states and design materials with tailored properties

• The product has been in development with over 400 athletes over the past several years and remains in testing
